intro: Sigesbeckia trinervata, commonly known as the three-veined bladdernut, is a herbaceous plant native to Asia. It belongs to the Asteraceae family and is characterized by its hairy, erect stems and opposite leaves with three distinct veins. The plant produces small, yellowish flowers that are clustered in heads, typical of the daisy family. Its fruits are schizocarps, splitting into two one-seeded parts when mature. Sigesbeckia trinervata is often found in moist, open habitats and has been used in traditional medicine for its purported health benefits.
